Articles.Content:
31 minutes ago, Sharpy said:

I don't know what were the motivations behind making the engine of Apollo CSM so huge - they *could* have done it with longer, weaker burns

The CSM engine is oversized because it was based on the existing AJ10 and originally specced to land the whole lunar mission on the moon (rather than splitting the mission into orbital and landing components in lunar orbit). Later, when it was decided to use lunar orbit rendezvous the development was far enough along that a delay to develop a smaller engine for it was unsatisfactory for the high pace of the space race, despite having twice the thrust.

More generally, it's incorrect to compare absolute nozzle length and say that the new engines are wrong. Vacuum engines have a high ratio of length to throat diameter, the new models shown don't violate this (remember the LV909 and presumably the LV303 have much less thrust than the other 1.25m engines, so their throat sizes are much smaller). 

I'd have to agree that the Poodle is a bit out to lunch, I think the current one was made short to make landers more feasible.

Check out this image included in the download of Porkjet's parts, it looks like the nozzles are given more realistic ratios: http://i.imgur.com/iINdJyL.jpg

6 minutes ago, Red Iron Crown said:

Check out this image included in the download of Porkjet's parts, it looks like the nozzles are given more realistic ratios: http://i.imgur.com/iINdJyL.jpg

15 hours ago, SQUAD said:

Chris (Porkjet) has wrapped up the overhauled rocket parts package which will be released for modders at the same time as the update 1.2 pre-release. It’s far from finished but hopefully these parts will help dealing with the anticipation. You can see some of these parts here.

Does this mean the parts will be included in the final release for 1.2?  "It's far from finished" leads me to believe it will not.

Check out this image included in the download of Porkjet's parts, it looks like the nozzles are given more realistic ratios: http://i.imgur.com/iINdJyL.jpg

I'm seeing a severe thrust nerf.

Rhino - 1200kN from 2000.

Mammoth - 3000 from 4000

Vector - 750 from 1000

I can only pray these are atmospheric values.

Actually Rhino weaker than Mainsail? madness.

Edited September 14, 2016 by Sharpy

I personally will mourn all the old models and textures as they fall one by one to the cries of 'too ugly'.

 

Don't take it personally, we'll all fall to the cries of "too ugly" when younger models show up

17 hours ago, SQUAD said:

making throttle controls (Including the X button) available in the map view at all times

Do not want!  The mapview is my refuge for using the Steam overlay!

18 minutes ago, The_Rocketeer said:

Do not want!  The mapview is my refuge for using the Steam overlay!

It was always available in map mode - while the navball was up at least.

What do you need the overlay for anyway? (Besides noone needs Steam to play KSP, I even always move it to another location.)

6 hours ago, richfiles said:

Note how huge the nozzle is?

While I agree that the Poodle is much smaller than it has any right to be, the Apollo SPS engine was quite extraordinarily huge. If you stand it next to a J-2, I'm not quite sure which one would be bigger. It's certainly much larger than whatever powers the Proton upper stages, using comparable propellants at 3-4x the thrust.

As @cfds said, that ship has sailed long ago. Besides, there's something to say in favor of magically shortening the engine, especially when it comes to landers. I won't defend it too much, but wrapping a number of tanks around an engine is tedious, drives up the part count, quickly becomes so wide that it won't fit well even on the largest rocket (which you don't need for a Mun lander), yadda yadda.

Short engines maybe are not the best solution, but they are a straightforward one. Which isn't entirely without merit.

Edited September 14, 2016 by Laie

12 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

It was always available in map mode - while the navball was up at least.

You have honed in on my objection. Score!

12 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

What do you need the overlay for anyway?

For the convenience of all or any of its manifold functions.

12 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

(Besides noone needs Steam to play KSP, I even always move it to another location.)

That really depends on whether you consider Steam an integral part of your KSP/videogaming experience. 99% of the time, I do. I use Steam as a social networking interface, I use the Steam browser in-game for all kinds of browser-based software including KSP-relevant spreadsheets. Strictly speaking you're right, I don't need to be able to do any of those things for KSP to work, but I do if I want to continue to use KSP the way I always have done until now.

Honestly, (assuming the part I quoted means what I think it means) this change seems pretty pointless to me - why would you ever want to throttle up in map-mode without at least having the navball up?

And before anybody starts suggesting work-arounds, yes I know there are plenty of ways to do the same thing, but most of them are less convenient or more complicated, and those that aren't are probably what I'll now have to train myself to start doing instead.

Edited September 14, 2016 by The_Rocketeer

4 hours ago, Sharpy said:

Not necessarily.

The efficiency (ISp) is in the nozzle shape - proportions, length to width.

The thrust is in the nozzle size.

You may freely make the engine quite small (though with the nozzle still quite elongated) with no significant loss of ISp, if you sacrifice thrust.

I don't know what were the motivations behind making the engine of Apollo CSM so huge - they *could* have done it with longer, weaker burns (and what they'd lose to Oberth Effect, they'd recuperate in lower engine mass). Maybe it was the mathematics - approximating impulsive burns better, computers of that time unable to calculate a long burn adequately enough.

Instead of Apollo, compare Merlin atmospheric and vacuum variants.

The one on the right is for vacuum, and it's actually pretty high thrust ( 411 kN, vs 60 of Terrier and 250 of Poodle ), as it still has to bring the rocket to the orbit from the point of stage separation.

It also has 342 seconds of ISp (vs 345 Terrier and 350 Poodle).

 

And compare it in size to Vector.

This is Vector IRL:

 

Now taking this into account - Poodle having a bit over half the thrust of Merlin (but a bit bigger ISp) and Terrier having about 15% the thrust - and as result, necessary size of Merlin, and comparing the size of Merlin-VAC to SSME,

 

tell me again they are too small.

 

Actually, that vacuum merlin you have in that picture is missing the bottom 3/4 of its bell.  It really is a very LARGE engine.

So yes, the stock vacuum engine models are too small.

Edit:

Here is a pic of the top of the engine, and the rest of its bell:


Edit here is a pic showing quite a few different engines, to scale (or very close).  Note the size of the vacuum merlins on the top row, compared to the RS-25 on the bottom row.  You can also see the relative size of the J-2, RS-68, RL10s, etc.  AJ10-137 is also shown in the middle row (from apollo SM).


Again, yes, the KSP vacuum engines are waaaaaaaay too small.

Edited September 14, 2016 by Shadowmage
@Shadowmage Oh, OK. I stand corrected

I like the parts. The exact visual is not important, what I like is that everything starts to get a unified, "Kerbal" style. Which is not as primitive "found on the side of the road" anymore... But we're not in version 0.18 anymore either!

I hope the point of releasing the source files is to give mod devsand example - "this is what kerbal looks like" and NOT "we're never going to release this, hope you guys can make something good out if it"?

Strictly speaking you're right, I don't need to be able to do any of those things for KSP to work, but I do if I want to continue to use KSP the way I always have done until now.

Honestly, (assuming the part I quoted means what I think it means) this change seems pretty pointless to me - why would you ever want to throttle up in map-mode without at least having the navball up?

And before anybody starts suggesting work-arounds, yes I know there are plenty of ways to do the same thing, but most of them are less convenient or more complicated, and those that aren't are probably what I'll now have to train myself to start doing instead.

Just to be the first to start with the suggestions.

6 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

Set KSP to run in borderless windowed mode so you can use your regular browser just like the overlay. Should behave and feel the same as your current workflow.

I appreciate your motives are kind, but the ideal outcome for me is for Squad not to change it unnecessarily. Perhaps I've misunderstood and they won't.

3 hours ago, Sharpy said:

I'm seeing a severe thrust nerf.

Rhino - 1200kN from 2000.

Mammoth - 3000 from 4000

Vector - 750 from 1000

I can only pray these are atmospheric values.

Actually Rhino weaker than Mainsail? madness.

The Rhino now looks much more like the J-2 and J-2X engines it was based on, and the vacuum thrust lowered to match as well, though it's actually STILL too high for a stock KSP version; the original J-2 had ~1000 Kn thrust, the J-2x would have been ~1300.  It's an upper stage engine, and shouldn't be capable of high sea-level thrust.

The full-width Rhino with the base plate also looks like the bottom thrust structure of the S-IVB stage, and with the compact version you'll be able to put five of them on the bottom of a 5m tank to recreate the Saturn V's second stage.

The Vector (and the Mammoth, which is 4 Vectors) probably could use a thrust nerf, to make it less OP and more suitable for both shuttle replicas and regular rockets.

4 hours ago, Red Iron Crown said:

Check out this image included in the download of Porkjet's parts, it looks like the nozzles are given more realistic ratios: http://i.imgur.com/iINdJyL.jpg

Jebus! That Poodle looks GOOD! I hope this is a sure thing! As I said, the Terrier 909 looks far better than before, cause the bell is now exposed enough to show the clear curvature. The Poodle design is great in that image you linked, and the 303 "Pug" looks better in that diagram than the previous image. It's clear now what's being rendered.

Yeah... If the Poodle is being upgraded witht hat new design, I'm totally satisfied!
Those new parts are krap

8 hours ago, JedTech said:

 What we wanted was rockets that aren't so floppy. Why implement such a complex and click-happy solution to the problem?

Autostruts were originally a workaround for a Unity issue with wheels in 1.1, they were made available for every part by request from the community, but they are not and never were meant to replace solid vessel engineering and actual strutting. They have many caveats and downsides. This is why they are not fully integrated with the game, and why they are gated behind the advanced tweakables option.

Edited September 14, 2016 by Arsonide

9 hours ago, JedTech said:

 What we wanted was rockets that aren't so floppy. Why implement such a complex and click-happy solution to the problem?

Please consider the sloppiness that KSP is becoming over the last few updates. It seems like squad has hired several coding minded individuals and lost a few human interface minded individuals. Not everything needs a button and configuration options. It may take more thought towards design, but it is always better to just "make it work" without all of the buttons and options.

Just out of curiosity, without a button how would you turn it on?

Regarding the vacuum engines, it really depends though, doesn't it? Comparing Merlin engines isn't wholly fair, since they use 9 engines on the first stage and so they need to be smaller. Ariane 5's single first stage Vulcain 2 engine is much more massive than even their largest upper stage engines. And it's overall capable of lifting much more than the Falcon 9. I'm not a rocket scientist, but from what I understand it's the width to length ratio that determines vacuum engine efficiency, not physical size, as other people have already noted. You don't see massive Apollo CSM sized engines on every satellite that operates in a vacuum, on manned spacecraft like Soyuz (I'm still not even sure where Soyuz's engines are located!), or on the various cargo missions to the ISS. (Sure, these other spacecraft didn't fly around the moon!)

Ariane 5 Vulcain-2 main stage vs. Vinci engine in ESC-B upper stage (EDIT: This is a proposed design. The HM7B engine in the current ESC-A upper stage is even smaller):

Plus, how it's all packed matters too. As far as I'm aware, the visible part of engine nozzles on the Soyuz second stage are very low profile. EDIT: In fact, if you look at the linked schematics for Porkjet's new designs, you can see that on the LV-909 now you can't even see the whole engine bell, let alone the chamber. The Poodle is now multiple engines, presumably so they could justify the performance while having a more realistic vacuum engine bell and still maintaining a low overall profile.

 

Edited September 14, 2016 by Binho
Adding more info.
